articleinfo.title: Fedict eID Trust Service Administrator Manual

abstract.para: This manual serves as an entry point for setting up the eID Trust Service. The target audience is system administrators.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document (in uppercase, as shown) are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] .

The eID Trust Service provides two major service artifacts:
eID Trust Service portal
Via this web portal citizens can check the validity of their eID certificates.
eID Trust Service validation web service
Via this SOAP web service Relying Parties (aka Service Providers) can check the validity of certificate paths. This web service is constructed according to the W3C XKMS2 web service standard.
Besides these two service artifacts, the eID Trust Service also comes with an Admin portal that allows administrators to manage the eID Trust Service via an easy to use web portal interface. In the following paragraphs we will use $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS as the (internal) web address where the eID Trust Service product has been deployed.

The source code of the Fedict eID Trust Service is publicly available and can be found at eID Trust Service Source Code . Please not that the Fedict eID Trust Service has dependencies on jTrust, a java library for trust validation of X509 certificates which can be found at jTrust source code .

section.title: Apache configuration under Redhat (Fedora)
section.para:
Activate the Apache HTTP Service via:
sudo chkconfig --level 345 httpd on chkconfig --list httpd sudo /etc/init.d/httpd restart
Install the SSL via:
sudo yum install mod_ssl.i686
Open up the iptables (under /etc/sysconfig/iptables ) firewall on the Apache server to allow for both HTTP (port 80) and HTTPS (port 443). Relevant iptables config lines are:
-A INPUT -p tcp -m state --state NEW -m tcp --dport 80 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -p tcp -m state --state NEW -m tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT
Check the firewall setting on Redhat (Fedora) via:
sudo cat /etc/sysconfig/iptables
Disable the NetworkManager via:
sudo /etc/init.d/NetworkManager stop sudo chkconfig --level 2345 NetworkManager off chkconfig --list NetworkManager sudo reboot
Enable the (static) network management via:
sudo chkconfig --level 345 network on chkconfig --list network
and check whether the levels 3, 4, and 5 are on.

section.title: eID Trust Service Portal
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service product, the eID Trust Service Portal is available at $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal/ . This web portal MUST be accessed over unilateral SSL. The SSL SHOULD be terminated on the front-end Apache HTTPD service so that the SSL information can be communicated to the JBoss Application Service over AJP. If such a setup is not possible this SHOULD be clearly communicated in advance to the eID Trust Service development team so they can properly configure the eID Applet Service that is used within the eID Trust Service Portal.

Add following configuration to your SSL site to accomplish this: <IfModule mod_proxy_ajp.c> ProxyRequests On ProxyVia On
<Location /eid-trust-service-portal> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-portal </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-admin-portal> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-admin-portal </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-ws> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-ws </Location> </IfModule> For Redhat (Fedora) you add this file under /etc/httpd/conf.d/trust-service.conf .

section.title: eID Trust Service Validation Web Service
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service product, the eID Trust Service validation web service is available at $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-ws/xkms2 This web service MUST be accessible via both HTTP and HTTPS (thus unilateral SSL). When this web service is accessed over plain HTTP, the service provides the possibility to sign the response messages using WS-Security. This can be configured in the Administrator portal.

section.title: eID Trust Service Admin Portal
section.para:
After deployment of the eID Trust Service, the eID Trust Service Admin Portal is available via: $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-admin-portal/
. This web portal MUST be accessed over unilateral SSL.

section.title: SNMP
section.para: The eID Trust Service yields different SNMP counters on port 7894.

section.title: Database
section.para: The eID Trust Service product requires a relational database with JDBC driver to operate.

section.title: Java Virtual Machine
section.para:
You need to have Java Sun 1.6.0_20 or higher installed. JDK or JRE are sufficient. These can be found at: Java download . After installation you will have to make sure the environment variable $JAVA_HOME is properly set and the java program is available in the $PATH . Under Redhat (Fedora) you can create a /etc/profile.d/java.sh file containing the following:
export JAVA_HOME=/usr/local/jdk1.6 export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH
Ensure Sun Java 1.6.0_20+ is installed via the following command:
java -version

section.title: JBoss Application Server
section.para:
The JBoss Application Server offers:
AJP at port: 8009
HTTP at port: 8080
HTTPS at port: 8443
AJP is preferred for the connection between the front-end Apache HTTPD and the JBoss Application Server.

section.title: Installation
section.para: This chapter explains how to install the Fedict eID Trust Service application.
The Fedict eID Trust Service has to be run on the JBoss Application Server . version 6.0.0.M2.

The Fedict eID Trust Service application is delivered in a customized database specific zip file. Unpacking this zip file you will notice 2 directories: ./jboss and ./sql . The ./jboss directory contains the JBoss application server, configured for your database and pre-packaged with the Fedict eID Trust Service application. The ./sql directory contains the database initialization scripts. MySQL and Oracle are supported.

It is also possible to run the Fedict eID Trust Service application using HSQL, which is the default configured database for the JBoss Application Server. You will have to use the JBoss distribution from the Fedict eID Applet project. This customized distribution has all necessary dependencies included to run the Fedict eID Trust Service. To install simply unzip the eID applet JBoss zip and copy the .ear file in ./jboss-as-distribution/server/all/deploy .

Please note that it is not recommended to use this setup in a production environment. As the HSQL database is in-memory and parsing of large CRL's also is memory intensive, you will run quickly into memory problems.

section.title: Database setup
section.para: Before trying to start the JBoss Application Server you will have to initialize your database. The initialization scripts can be found in the ./sql directory. There are 3 scripts, one to create the database account, one to create the Fedict eID Trust Service database and one to initialize its tables. The default username/password for trust database is trust/trust . Please note that if you wish to change this, you will have to manually modify the datasource in the JBoss distribution. The configuration for this can be found in /jboss/server/all/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml .

The Fedict eID Trust Service has been successfully tested on:
MySQL v5.0 and v5.1
Oracle 10.2.0.1.0

section.title: MySQL database setup on Redhat (Fedora)
section.para:
Following is needed for setting up the MySQL database on Redhat (Fedora):
sudo yum install mysql-server.i686 sudo /etc/init.d/mysqld start sudo mysqladmin -u root password 'secret' mysql -u root -p < mysql-create-account.sql mysql -u trust -p < mysql-create-database.sql mysql -u trust -p trust < mysql-trust-service-ddl.sql
Check the database via:
mysql -u trust -p trust SHOW tables; QUIT;
Check whether the MySQL service will be started at boot time via:
chkconfig --list mysqld
Enable the MySQL service via:
sudo chkconfig --level 345 mysqld on
Drop an existing MySQL database via: mysql -u trust -p DROP DATABASE trust; QUIT;

section.title: Oracle database setup on Debian
section.para:
Download the Oracle 10g Release 2 package @ Oracle 10g Release 2 . For further installation please check out Oracle installation on Debian . The ./sql directory contains initialization scripts for setting up an Oracle tablespace in the default XE database. Simply execute:
sqlplus @oracle-init-trust-service.sql
This might require settings some environment variables:
export ORACLE_HOME=/usr/lib/oracle/xe/app/oracle/product/10.2.0/server export PATH=$ORACLE_HOME/bin:$PATH
Check the database via:
sqlplus trust/trust; SQL> select table_name from user_tables; SQL> exit

section.title: PostgreSQL database setup on Redhat (Fedora)
section.para:
Following is needed for setting up the PostgreSQL database on Redhat (Fedora):
sudo yum install postgresql-server.i686 sudo service postgresql initdb sudo /etc/init.d/postgresql start

Check whether the PostgreSQL service will be started at boot time via:
chkconfig --list postgresql

Enable the PostgreSQL service via:
sudo chkconfig --level 345 postgresql on

As JPA requires prepared transactions we need to enable this feature on the PostgreSQL database. Change the PostgreSQL configuration file /var/lib/pgsql/data/postgresql.conf :
max_prepared_transactions = 10

Change the PostgreSQL client authentication by editing the following lines in /var/lib/pgsql/data/pg_hba.conf :
local all all trust host all all 127.0.0.1/32 trust

Create a PostgreSQL user and database via:
psql -U postgres < postgresql-create-account-database.sql

Create the eID Trust Service tables in the PostgreSQL trust database via:
psql -d trust -U trust -W -f postgresql-trust-service-ddl.sql
Check the database via: psql -d trust -U trust SELECT table_name FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema = 'public'; \q
Drop an existing database via: psql -U postgres DROP DATABASE trust; \q

section.title: Resources
section.para: As the harvesting of large CRLs can be memory intensive, the JBoss Application Server has been tweaked so the JVM can use more memory. By default it is set to reserve a total of 1GB of heap space. The configuration can be found in ./jboss/bin/run.conf See Useful links for more info on tweaking this.
As to the amount of network traffic, this is highly related as to how CRL caching is configured.

section.title: Clustering
section.para: Following is needed for a basic clustering with load balancing setup. Since JBoss 6 M1, clustering has been simplified as mod_cluster . Unlike mod_jk and mod_proxy , mod_cluster leverages an additional connection between the application server nodes and httpd. The application server nodes use this connection to transmit server-side load balance factors and lifecycle events back to httpd via a custom set of HTTP methods, affectionately called the Mod-Cluster Management Protocol (MCMP). This additional feedback channel allows mod_cluster to offer a level of intelligence and granularity not found in other load balancing solutions.

section.title: JBoss Configuration
section.para:
By default sticky sessions will be enabled. Yet at the time of writing their is an issue in mod_cluster if you do not explicitely specify a jvmRoute . See MODCLUSTER-146 for more info. Do this as follows:
> vim jboss/server/all/deploy/jbossweb.sar/server.xml // add jvmRoute="node01" in <Engine name="jboss.web" ... >

section.title: Httpd Configuration
section.para:
First you will have to download the mod_cluster 's needed modules @ mod_cluster . After having completed the installation, here is a basic httpd.conf setup:
LoadModule proxy_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_proxy.so LoadModule proxy_ajp_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_proxy_ajp.so LoadModule slotmem_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_slotmem.so LoadModule manager_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_manager.so LoadModule proxy_cluster_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_proxy_cluster.so LoadModule advertise_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_advertise.so
LogLevel debug
CreateBalancers 1
<VirtualHost *:80>
<Location /mod_cluster-manager> SetHandler mod_cluster-manager
Order deny,allow Deny from all Allow from all # Allow from 192.168.7. </Location>
<Directory /> Order deny,allow Deny from all Allow from all </Directory>
ProxyPass /eid-trust-service-admin-portal balancer://mycluster/eid-trust-service-admin-portal
KeepAliveTimeout 60 MaxKeepAliveRequests 0 ManagerBalancerName mycluster AdvertiseFrequency 5
</VirtualHost>
Beware in this setup the mod_cluster-manager is set open for testing purposes. This way you can view the connected nodes @ ./mod_cluster-manager . More information on more advanced setups can be found in the Useful links section.

section.title: Starting
section.para:
After you have correctly setup your database, you can start the application by executing following command:
./jboss/bin/run.sh -b 0.0.0.0 -c all &
. The option -b 0.0.0.0 is to change the bind address of the server so its available to all interfaces.

warning.title: eID Trust Service Administrator registration
warning.para: The first time you start the eID Trust Service you should register a trust service administrator via the admin portal.

section.para:
After the application has started, it will have initialized itself with 4 trust domains.
eID Authentication Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE-AUTH )
eID Non Repudiation Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE )
eID National Registry Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE-NAT-REG )
Belgian TSA Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE-TSA )
The default trust domain will be set to the eID Authentication Trust Domain.

In order to function properly, the application needs to be able to make outgoing calls for CRL, OCSP, TSP and NTP. If you are running behind a proxy, you can setup the proxy using the administration webapp.
CRL downloading for the Belgian eID Trust Domains are typically something like http://crl.eid.belgium.be/eidc200501.crl . The URI is retrieved from the specific certificate.
OCSP requests for the Belgian eID Trust Domains are sent to http://ocsp.eid.belgium.be . The URI is again retrieved from the specific certificate.
TSP requests can be used for clock drift detection and the location is configurable in the Administrator portal.
The NTP protocol can also be used for clock drift detection and again the location is configurable in the Administrator portal.

section.title: Stopping
section.para:
Graceful shutdown can be accomplished via:
./jboss/bin/shutdown.sh -S
After this you can check if shutdown completed properly via:
ps -ef | grep java

section.title: Init script for Redhat (Fedora)
section.para: Copied orginal supplied init script: cp $JBOSS_HOME/bin/jboss_init_redhat.sh /etc/init.d/jboss Changed permissions on new jboss init script: sudo chmod 755 /etc/init.d/jboss You might need to changed the following in the JBoss script: JBOSS_HOME="location of your JBoss distribution" JBOSS_USER="the user that will be used to run the JBoss application server under" JAVAPTH="the location of your JVM" JBOSS_CONF="all" To bind to the correct IP address, this line modified: JBOSS_BIND_ADDR=${JBOSS_HOST:+"-b $JBOSS_HOST"} to JBOSS_BIND_ADDR=${JBOSS_BIND_ADDR:-"-b your.ip.address.here"} To get a log file, this line modified: JBOSS_CONSOLE=${JBOSS_CONSOLE:-"/dev/null"} to JBOSS_CONSOLE=${JBOSS_CONSOLE:-"/location/of/your/logs/jboss-console.log"

section.title: Transaction timeouts
section.para:
The downloading and processing of large CRLs can sometimes take a lot of time. This can lead to internal transaction timeouts. By default, the custom JBoss MySQL and Oracle Distributions have a transaction timeout configured of 1200 seconds or 20 minutes. Which should be sufficient. If this still proves to be insufficient, this can be changed in jboss/server/default/deploy/transaction-jboss-beans.xml Look for following line and change accordingly:
<property name="defaultTimeout">1200</property>
. After changing this the JBoss Application Server has to be restarted as followed:
./jboss/bin/shutdown.sh -S ./jboss/bin/run.sh -b 0.0.0.0 -c all
Please note to check if shutdown was completed before starting.

section.title: Configuring Redhat (Fedora) as an eID Trust Service
section.para:
The network interface should not be managed by the NetworkManager but should start at boot time. Check that /etc/sysconfig/network_scripts/ifcfg_eth0 contains following lines:
ONBOOT=yes NM_CONTROLLED=no USERCTL=no
Disable the graphical user interface at startup by setting the runlevel in /etc/inittab to 3:
id:3:initdefault:

section.title: Configuration of the NTP-client on Redhat (Fedora)
section.para:
Configure your NTP servers via /etc/ntp.conf . Configure the NTP service via:
sudo chkconfig --level 345 ntpd on chkconfig --list ntpd
Start the NTP service via:
sudo /etc/init.d/ntpd start
.

section.title: JBoss Logging
section.para:
The JBoss Application Server's logging configuration can be found in ./jboss/server/default/deploy/jboss-logging.xml . All logging from the Fedict eID Trust Service is configured to a seperate log file which can be found in ./jboss/server/default/log/fedict.log . By default the logging granularity is set to DEBUG . You can change this by changing the level of the configured Fedict logger:
<logger category="be.fedict"> <level name="DEBUG" /> <handlers> <handler-ref name="FEDICT" /> </handlers> </logger>
In the same way here you can change JBoss' logging too.
Production configuration
For production configurations you should change the logging from DEBUG to ERROR .

section.title: Database
section.para: To view the contents of the database behind the FedICT eID Trust Service, one can use the SQuirrel SQL Client . This SQL client allows you to view the structure of any JDBC compliant database.

To be able to connect to your HSQL/MySQL/Oracle database you will need to configure a JDBC driver. You can download the drivers @ MySQL JDBC Driver and
Oracle JDB Driver
. Configure your driver in SQuirrel SQL by selecting the appropriate one, select Modify Driver... and add your JDBC driver jar in the Extra Class Path tab.

When you are done with this, you can configure the connection to the database by adding a new Alias . Select the appropriate driver, and configure the URL, username and password as is configured in the FedICT eID Trust Service datasource file ( /jboss/server/default/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml ).

section.title: Administration Portal
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with an administration portal. This portal allows you to setup your network proxy if any, manage trust domains and other aspects of the service.

section.title: Administrator registration
section.para:
To authenticate to the administrator portal, an eID authentication will be performed. If the service was freshly installed, the first successfull authentication will be automatically registered as administrator. Subsequent administrators will have to be accepted by this one. There are two ways to accomplish this:
Perform a login which will add you as a pending administrator which can subsequently be approved by an administrator.
Ask another administrator who is logged to register you from within the admin portal. You can find this in the
.

section.title: Administrators
section.para: Here you can view existing and pending administrators, approve pending administrators, remove administrators and register an additional one. To register an additional one, a full eID authentication has to be performed of this new administrator.

section.title: WS-Security Configuration
section.para: The eID Trust Service Validation Web Service has the possibility to optionally sign its response message using WS-Security. The keystore to be used for this can be configured here. There is support for JKS, PKCS#11 and PKCS#12 keystores. The keystore path in case of PKCS#11 is the path to the configuration file which will be used by the Sun PKCS#11 provider.

section.title: Network Configuration
section.para: If you are operating behind a proxy, you can setup this in here and enable or disable the proxy configuration.

section.title: Clock Drift Detection
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with built in support for NTP and TSP. TSP or Timestamp Protocol is a protocol used for certifying timestamps. A timestamp request will be sent to the configured TSA server, returning a timestamp response containing a timestamp token. The received timestamp token will be used for clock drift detection.

section.title: Information Message
section.para: The information message to be shown on $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal can be configured here for all available languages of the FedICT eID Trust Service Portal.

section.title: Virtual Trust Domains
section.para: Virtual trust domains are a group of existing trust domains. Users of the eID Trust Service Validation Web Service have the possibility to specify a virtual trust domain to validate against all of its trust domains configured.

section.title: Trust Domains
section.para: You can add, modify, remove trust domains here. Also you can set the default trust domain for the FedICT eID Trust Service. This trust domain will be used in the eID Trust Service Validation Web Service if no specific trust domain was specified. For each trust domain you can specify whether or not CRL caching should be used, which trust points lie under this trust domain and which certificate contraints are too be enforced when validating against this trust domain.

section.title: Trust Points
section.para: For each trust point, you can specify a cron expression for specifying the CRL cache refresh interval. Such a refresh includes refreshing all underlying CA's that have been cached. You can also refresh the CRL cache immediately here for debugging purposes. For each trust point you can see the list of CA's associated with this trust point and for each CA refresh the cache individually.

section.title: SNMP
section.para:
The FedICT eID Trust Service has several SNMP counters available. These counters can be retrieved by invoking the command:
snmpget -v 2c -c public localhost:7894 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.0.0
. The available SNMP counters are:
# of validations ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.0.0 )
# of CRL cache refreshes ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.1.0 )
# of CRL cache hits ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.2.0 )
# of CRL cache misses ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.3.0 )
CRL cache hit % ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.4.0 )
# of CRL download failures ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.5.0 )
# of OCSP request failures ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.6.0 )
